citation.article-title: Methanosaeta concilii gen. nov., sp. nov. ("Methanothrix concilii") and Methanosaeta thermoacetophila nom. rev., comb. nov.

p.s: Methanosaeta (Me. tha. no. sae´ta. N.L.n. methanum, methane; Gr.n. saeta, bristle; N.L. fem. n. Methanosaeta, methane [-producing] bristle)
The cells of members of this genus are obligately anaerobic, gram-negative, nonmotile, nonsporeforming rods with flat ends.
Single cells are 2 to 6 μm long and 0.8 to 1.3 μm wide and are enclosed inside a tubular, proteinaceous sheath.
Growth can occur as long flexible filaments.
Each filament consists of a chain of cells which are separated by spacer plugs and are enclosed by a continuous sheath.
Acetic acid is used as the sole source of energy, with the production of about equimolar amounts of CH4 and CO2 as the metabolic end products.
None of the other common methanogenic substrates, such as H2-CO2, formate, methanol, or methylamines, can serve as sole sources of energy.
Acetate and CO4 are sole carbon sources.
The type species of the genus Methanosaeta is Methanosaeta concilii.
